metadata.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellant joined railway service as Signaller Telegraphist in August 1924.
Promoted as Section Controller in 1942, Deputy Chief Controller in 1947, Chief Controller in 1950, all in Class III service.
On March 31, 1951, appellant appeared before selection board for Assistant Superintendent Railway Telegraphs (Class II gazetted post) and was selected out of seven candidates.
Notice of appointment issued on July 2, 1951, appointing appellant to officiate as Asst. Spdt. Rly. Telegraphs, Headquarters Office, Class II service, vice Mr. Sahu Ram.
Appellant relieved Mr. Sahu Ram and took charge on afternoon of July 3, 1951.
Earned two increments on July 4, 1952 and July 4, 1953.
On April 28, 1953, Gouri Shankar S.T.E.I. Hd. Qrs. made adverse remarks in confidential report for year ending March 31, 1953.
Confidential report confirmed by Shri Sen, C.S.T.E., on May 25, 1953, with additional adverse opinion.

General Manager Shri Karnail Singh remarked on June 11, 1953: 'I am disappointed to read these reports. He should revert as a subordinate till he makes good the short-comings noticed in this chance of his as an officer.' Portions underlined in red to be communicated.
Adverse remarks communicated to appellant by confidential letter No. E-106/180 dated June 29, 1953.
Appellant made representation against remarks on July 24, 1953.

General Manager issued notice No. 940-E/14 E.I.A. on August 19, 1953, transferring Shri Bishambar Nath Chopra to officiate as Assistant Signal and Tele-communication Engineer Telegraphs vice appellant, who on relief reverts to Class III appointment.
Appellant appealed to General Manager on August 20, 1953, for reconsideration.
Appellant appealed to Railway Board on October 19, 1953, and made representation to President of India.

Railway Board wrote to General Manager on February 2, 1955: Reversion stands for unsatisfactory work but not a bar to future promotion if work improves; language in representation unbecoming; watch work till end March 1955 for possible promotion as Assistant Transportation Superintendent.
Railway Board communication relayed to appellant on February 17, 1955.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 on February 9, 1955.
Single Judge Mr. Justice Harnam Singh allowed writ on April 15, 1955, holding reduction in rank without opportunity under Art. 311(2).
Division Bench (Bhandari C.J. and Falshaw J.) reversed on January 19, 1956, in Letters Patent Appeal No. 28 of 1955, dismissing writ.
Punjab High Court granted certificate of fitness on August 20, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order passed by the General Manager on August 19, 1953, reverting the appellant from officiating Class II post to substantive Class III post amounted to a reduction in rank within the meaning of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: The reversion was a punishment by reduction in rank without reasonable opportunity to show cause as required by Art. 311(2).

respondent_arguments.text: The reversion was not a reduction in rank by way of punishment but a termination of officiating arrangement due to unsatisfactory work, not attracting Art. 311(2).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Articles 310 and 311; service rules distinguishing punishment from reversion of officiating post

court_reasoning.text: Art. 310 adopts pleasure doctrine subject to Art. 311 protections against dismissal/removal by subordinate authority and without opportunity for dismissal/removal/reduction in rank.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art. 311 applies to all government servants, permanent or temporary/officiating.

court_reasoning.text: Dismissal, removal, reduction in rank in Art. 311 denote major punishments under service rules requiring procedure; termination under contract/rules not punishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test: whether servant had right to post/rank (substantive permanent, fixed-term temporary, quasi-permanent) or visited with penal consequences.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant appointed to officiate Class II post (no substantive right); reversion to substantive Class III not forfeiture of right, no penal consequences (future promotion possible), hence not punishment under Art. 311(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Officiating appointment terminable at pleasure without Art. 311(2) unless punitive.

holdings.text: Reversion from officiating higher post to substantive lower post is not reduction in rank by way of punishment under Art. 311(2) if no right to post and no penal consequences.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Abdul Majid
precedents_cited.relevance: Indian law did not adopt English pleasure doctrine in entirety; public servants can enforce claims.
English common law: servants hold at Crown's pleasure.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lucas v. Lucas and High Commissioner for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied English pleasure doctrine to Indian Civil Servant.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. Venkata Rao v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Rules under 1915 Act regulate but do not create enforceable rights against pleasure.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. A. Venkataraman v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Arts. 310-311 impose fetters on pleasure for specified punishments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satish Chander Anand v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Contractual termination (e.g., month's notice) not dismissal/removal under Art. 311.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Compulsory retirement under rules not punishment attracting Art. 311(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Jayanti Prasad v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Arts. 310-311 apply to temporary as well as permanent; termination not always punishment.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Pleasure doctrine qualified by protections against subordinate dismissal/removal and no opportunity for dismissal/removal/reduction in rank.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Substantially reproduced in Arts. 310-311; introduced opportunity before reduction.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1919
statutes_cited.relevance: First statutory recognition of pleasure with subordinate authority qualification.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Service (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined penalties; explanations distinguish termination from punishment.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railway Establishment Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Penalties for railway servants; note excludes officiating reversion from removal/dismissal.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Definitions of lien, officiating, permanent/temporary posts; pay cessation on dismissal.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Division Bench's decision reversing the Single Judge, holding that the reversion was not a reduction in rank by way of punishment under Art. 311(2) as the appellant had no substantive right to the officiating post and no penal consequences ensued.

key_quotes.text: "The real test for determining whether the termination of the service of a Government servant is by way of punishment is to ascertain whether the servant, but for such termination, had the right to hold the post."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines key test for Art. 311(2) applicability.

key_quotes.text: "If the case satisfies either of the two tests then it must be held that the servant has been punished."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Outlines tests: right to post or penal consequences.

key_quotes.text: "Art. 311 applies to all classes of Government servants mentioned in it and that it makes no difference whether they are permanent, quasi-permanent, officiating, temporary or on probation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
